I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
1.  The proposed Surkhandarya Regional Road Project will rehabilitate the 111-kilometer (km) 
Derbent  to  Denau  Road  (the  project  road),  linking  the  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic 
Cooperation (CAREC) Corridors 3b (Russian Federation to Middle East and South Asia via 
Dushanbe) and 6b (Europe to Middle East and South Asia via Dushanbe).  
 
2.  As a key node in an international road network, Uzbekistan is a contributor to as well as a 
beneficiary of regional integration to enhance global connectivity, increase international trade and 
ultimately diversify livelihoods in Central Asia. Three major CAREC corridors, 2, 3b and 6b, 
provide connectivity with other Central Asian countries.  By strengthening this link, the project 
road will support the broader CAREC corridor network and thus contribute to regional integration.  
 
3.  The core problem of the road subsector in Uzbekistan is inefficient road infrastructure, 
which leads to reduced mobility, unsafe roads and limited access to markets and services which 
disproportionately affect women. The proposed project will contribute to addressing this core 
problem through two outputs. 
 
4.  Output 1. Derbent to Denau highway section in Surkhandarya region rehabilitated. The 
road will be rehabilitated to meet an international roughness index of 3m/km. The journey time 
between Derbent to Denau will fall from the current 3 hours to 1.5 hours, with average design 
speeds of 100 km/hr. The improved road will provide Uzbekistan with a higher standard link to 
ports in Pakistan. At the national level it will improve domestic connectivity along the road corridor. 
 
5.  Output 2. Institutional capacity of the CR improved and an intelligent transport system 
installed and made operational to provide smart and efficient transport mobility. The institutional 
capacity of CR for managing the core road network, including planning, design and maintenance 
strategies  will  be  improved.  Training,  workshops  and  manuals  on  road  construction  and 
maintenance for the road units in the project area will be provided. The intelligent transport system 
(ITS) will be introduced to channel information to the public in real time including presence of 
collision risks, road conditions, weather conditions, and road works ahead. This will improve 
driving experience, safety, road capacity, traffic flow and pollution levels. 
 
6.  These solutions will result in the following outcome: The road network in the Surkhandarya 
region made more efficient and safe. The project will be aligned with the following impacts: 
(i)  implementation  of  targeted  programs  to  build  affordable  housing,  development  and 
modernization  of  road  transport,  engineering,  communications  and  social  infrastructure 
achieved;1 and (ii) competitive corridors across the CAREC region established. 2  
 
7.  Overall, the proposed project is aligned with the ADB’s Strategy 2030, which gives special 
attention to the needs of landlocked economies and supports improving regional connectivity and 
competitiveness by addressing cross-border infrastructure needs. It is also consistent with ADB’s 
Country Partnership Strategy 2019–2023 for Uzbekistan.  
 
8.  The estimated cost of the ensuing project is $200 million. The ADB is considering a loan 
of $180 million from its regular Ordinary Capital Resources to finance the project. Counterpart 
financing from the Government of $20 million would finance land and resettlement costs, and

II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
9.  The proposed TRTA will help the government of Uzbekistan to prepare the proposed 
ensuring project.3 The TRTA will ensure that the project will be prepared to acceptable technical, 
safeguards, and procurement standards. The ensuing project is expected to meet the “high 
readiness” criteria before Board consideration and help develop the capacity of CR to implement 
the ensuing project. The TRTA will also develop the appropriate institutional conditions to allow 
the sound development of the road subsector in future years. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
10.  Output 1: Due diligence and procurement documents for the proposed project 
completed. The TRTA will (i) undertake a detailed review of the technical designs for the 
rehabilitation of the project road that have been prepared by the government design institute and 
if need be, propose amendments to the designs to align with ADB and international requirements; 
(ii)  prepare  an  updated  sector  assessment;  (iii)  prepare  economic  and  financial  analyses; 
(iv) prepare required safeguards, social, and gender-related documents; (v) assist the CR with 
preparing the national feasibility study (in accordance with Presidential Resolution No. 3857);4 
(vi) prepare bidding documents; and (vii) assist the CR with procuring contracts for the works. 
  
11.  The key deliverables will be bidding documents; safeguards, poverty, social, and gender 
analysis reports; draft Gender Action Plan; summary poverty reduction and social strategy and other 
documents necessary for (i) ADB processing of financing for the project; (ii) the government’s 
approval of the project; and (iii) civil works successfully procured with contracts ready to sign when 
the project financing has become effective. 
 
12.  Output 2: CR capacity in network management and maintenance, project preparation 
and implementation improved. This output will provide CR with capacity development and training 
programs on ITS; civil works procurement and contract management for internationally financed 
projects; and safeguard compliance and monitoring.  
 
13.  On ITS, the TRTA will help design a system that is best suited to the needs of the project 
road.  
 
14.  On procurement, this output will assist CR in conducting the strategic procurement planning 
analysis. The principles behind ADB’s procurement policy and regulations will be explained, and 
the  strategic  procurement  planning  analysis  will  be  conducted  to  define  a  fit-for-purpose 
procurement plan. Training, workshops and manuals on road construction and maintenance for 
the road units in the project area will be provided.

15.  On safeguards, the output will provide hands-on support to CR’s staff in charge of 
environmental and social safeguards, so that CR may develop an understanding of ADB’s 
Safeguards Policy Statement 2009 and associated procedures and regulations. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TRTA is estimated to cost $1.2 million, financed by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special 
Fund 6. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. 
 
17.  The government will provide support in the form of the technical designs and documents 
prepared  by  its  Design  Institute,  counterpart  staff,  office  accommodation,  and  other  in-kind 
contributions. 
 
18.  The government has been informed that approval of the TRTA does not commit ADB to 
finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The CR will be the TRTA executing agency. ADB’s Central and West Asia Department, 
Transport and Communications Division will be responsible for coordinating, supervising, and 
implementing all TRTA activities, including recruitment and monitoring of consultants (Table 1).  
 
20.  Procurement of goods if required, will be carried out in accordance with ADB Technical 
Assistance Staff Instructions and relevant guidance notes. The equipment procured under the 
technical assistance will be turned over to the government at the end of the TRTA.

21.  The TRTA will require approximately 46 person-months of international consultants and 
56 person-months of national consultants’ inputs. Of these inputs, 39 and 46 person-months 
respectively will be engaged through a firm, and the remaining 7 and 10 person months respectively 
will be engaged as individual consultants. Consultants will provide expertise in road and structural 
design, procurement and contract management, transport economics and financial assessments, 
institutional assessment and capacity development, environment and resettlement safeguards and 
social and gender development.  
 
22.  The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Policy and 
Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers for Goods, Works, Nonconsulting and Consulting 
Services (2017, as amended from time to time). 
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,200,000.00 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Uzbekistan for preparing the Surkhandarya Regional Road Project, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.
